prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G15 A
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(2-1) and 230GHz continuum imaging of 10 of the most dust-rich, isolated ETGs in the local Universe.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our primary science goal is to detect the 12CO(2-1) line to spatially resolve the molecular gas in our sample of dusty early-type galaxies (ETGs). We will also simultaneously detect the spatially resolved continuum emission from cold dust at 230 GHz. Our choice of observed frequency is motivated by the spatial extent of the sources being well-matched to the spatial resolution and maximum resolvable scale available in ALMA band 6. The dust continuum is sufficiently bright at 230 GHz and the 12CO(2-1) line allows us to measure the distribution, kinematics and mass of the molecular gas in our sample of ETGs.
Molecular gas in ETGs is usually found to have a typical radial extent of ~1 kpc; Young et al. 2011, Davis et al. 2013), therefore we expect the molecular gas in our ETGs (major axis R_e~5-10" - see Table 1, minor axis R_e~3-5") to be within the field-of-view (~26") at 230 GHz in one single pointing. This should also be true of the dust emission, as Alatalo et al. (2013) find filamentary dust is spatially coincident with the molecular gas. A spatial resolution of 0.5" (corresponding to scales of 0.26-0.55 kpc at z=0.025-0.058) will allow us to resolve the extent of any molecular gas disks in the ETGs. Our sources will not contain emission on scales larger than 10" which is within the maximum recoverable scale in band 6; we do not require use of the ACA. Our on-source integrations are >2 minutes per source, therefore we will have sufficient UV coverage with the 12m array to map the gas and dust at 0.5" resolution.
We estimated the mass of H_2 in our ETGs using the measured dust masses and a conservative gas-to-dust ratio of 50. We estimate the peak CO flux assuming a Galactic X_CO factor and a line width of 150 km/s (Young et al. 2011). Our RMS estimates assume a 12CO(2-1)/12CO(1-0) ratio of 1 (Bayet et al. 2012) and one beam per channel. One 1.875 GHz spectral window will cover the 12CO(2-1) line, with dual-polarisation 976kHz (1.3 km/s) channels. After binning to 10.5km/s this ensures that we have at least 14 channels across the width of the CO line and a 5 sigma detection per channel which is sufficient to measure the velocity of the gas.
The remaining three spectral windows will record continuum in three 1.875 GHz windows in 31 MHz (40 km/s) channels. The continuum flux is estimated from a modified blackbody fit to the 100-500um fluxes assuming a dust emissivity index of 2.0. The continuum RMS assumes 5 beams across each source and a signal-to-noise of 3. Some objects in this sample have radio point sources in their cores, however extrapolating the 1.4GHz flux density measurements to 230 GHz (assuming a power-law slope of -0.8 for star-forming galaxies) shows that it is very unlikely that in these galaxies the dust continuum will be contaminated by radio synchrotron emission.
Our sensitivity estimates should ensure an accurate measurement of the distribution of the dust and molecular gas that is central to our science goals. Our targets are grouped so that sources within an individual science goal are within 10 degrees of each other and also share similar sensitivity requirements. The G12 field is split into two separate science goals as there are a wide range of sensitivities for these sources.
We do not need observations with the ACA and have we no special requirements on bandpass accuracy, data rates, scheduling or calibration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(2-1) and 230GHz continuum imaging of 10 of the most dust-rich, isolated ETGs in the local Universe.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Using 7.6 hours of ALMA time we propose a study of the resolved cold dust and molecular gas emission in a sample of 10 nearby (z~0.05), isolated, massive early-type galaxies (ETGs) which harbour significant (~10^7 M_Sun) masses of dust. The dust masses of these ETGs are far larger than can be produced by evolved stars, yet it is unclear whether mergers can supply and sustain the high dust masses in these ETGs. We require each dusty ETG to have swallowed a galaxy with a dust mass equivalent to that of the Milky Way, yet the majority of galaxies do not appear morphologically disturbed. Coupled with the wealth of ancillary multiwavelength data, resolving the spatial distribution of the dust and gas emission and gas kinematics will allow us to definitively determine whether the cold ISM in these isolated, dusty ETGs is grown in the ISM or accreted from external sources. Revealing the importance of accretion will give insight into processes which shape galaxies at a late stage in their evolution, at a time when these galaxies are thought to have undergone quenching of their star formation.
